custom.caption: The Chief Engineer explaining stuff  to a couple of floozies that happened to be walking by...
Exploring a worker's tiny cottage
The entrance to the village - Michael of course is wearing an appropriate hat...
The place where they measure out ingredients... I think. But again, the colours....
A view of the village
More artsy fartsy colours....Impressive machinery!
The cottage kitchen
On the wall in the worker's cottage - seemed so appropriate - it must have been a hard life especially in the bitter winters.
I have no idea what this enormous thing does but I loved the artsy fartsy colours of the pic!
The Big Cheese stamping the payslips
Peering up a little cobbled street in Bakewell..
A most beautiful building, characteristic of the area.
Making a beeline for the pub....
Changing the fashion outlook of the residents of Bakewell forever!
A bit of history - Thornbridge Brewery was founded at Thornbridge Hall, an old country house near Bakewell.
Some serious beer tasting going on here - Lauren's depth of concentration is particularly impressive.
Ambling along the River Wye, sipping coffee - so picturesque.
Thornbridge Barrel Room to sample a few craft beers...

custom.alt: Many dry river beds had to be negotiated through valleys. A welcome break from climbing.
custom.caption: Many dry river beds had to be negotiated through valleys. A welcome break from climbing.

custom.alt: The remains of Gabriel's home - hard to imagine how difficult life was. Peaceful, though. Would we want to swap? Maybe.
custom.caption: The remains of Gabriel's home - hard to imagine how difficult life was. Peaceful, though. Would we want to swap? Maybe.

custom.alt: The bedroom at Cobb Cottage - the bed was luxurious!
custom.caption: The bedroom at Cobb Cottage - the bed was luxurious!

custom.alt: This gentleman is resident at Cobb Cottage where we overnighted before the long drive home.
custom.caption: This gentleman is resident at Cobb Cottage where we overnighted before the long drive home.

custom.alt: Investigating Gabriels Pools in a crevice between the rocks. Gabriel actually lived close by here at the end of the 19th Century, beginning of the 20th Century.
custom.caption: Investigating Gabriels Pools in a crevice between the rocks. Gabriel actually lived close by here at the end of the 19th Century, beginning of the 20th Century.

custom.alt: Our first night's stop before starting the Leopard Trail - beautiful.
custom.caption: Our first night's stop before starting the Leopard Trail - beautiful.

custom.alt: A Karoo swimming pool - at 35 degrees C it's a must to hop in in one's hiking clothes.
custom.caption: A Karoo swimming pool - at 35 degrees C it's a must to hop in in one's hiking clothes.

custom.alt: For Steph - can you spot the Blue Headed Lizard. He loves this type of country.
custom.caption: For Steph - can you spot the Blue Headed Lizard. He loves this type of country.

custom.alt: The start of a big climb.
custom.caption: The start of a big climb.

custom.alt: View from the bed at Cobb Cottage
custom.caption: View from the bed at Cobb Cottage

custom.alt: Evening chilling while the Chef performs his duties behind the scenes.
custom.caption: Evening chilling while the Chef performs his duties behind the scenes.

custom.alt: Cock on a Rock without A Frock - apologies to the makers of Priscilla Queen of the Desert. We climbed up here from the valley below - a hectic climb.
custom.caption: Cock on a Rock without A Frock - apologies to the makers of Priscilla Queen of the Desert. We climbed up here from the valley below - a hectic climb.

custom.alt: A swanky outside toilet that flushes!
custom.caption: A swanky outside toilet that flushes!

custom.alt: Contemplating another climb.
custom.caption: Contemplating another climb.

custom.alt: The huts at our camps were all wood with huge glass walls and windows - amazing views to wake up to.
custom.caption: The huts at our camps were all wood with huge glass walls and windows - amazing views to wake up to.

custom.alt: Late afternoon deep in the Karoo.
custom.caption: Late afternoon deep in the Karoo.

custom.alt: Another wonderful Karoo bath - glorious on a sunny day!
custom.caption: Another wonderful Karoo bath - glorious on a sunny day!

custom.alt: My Fire Master and Chef for the duration of our trip.
custom.caption: My Fire Master and Chef for the duration of our trip.

custom.alt: An early morning view of Base Camp - the 60 km Leopards Trail starts and finishes here.
custom.caption: An early morning view of Base Camp - the 60 km Leopards Trail starts and finishes here.

custom.alt: The previous week's rain brought with it gorgeous flowers everywhere. We were so lucky to miss the rain and get the flowers.
custom.caption: The previous week's rain brought with it gorgeous flowers everywhere. We were so lucky to miss the rain and get the flowers.

custom.alt: So much beauty in such an arid place.
custom.caption: So much beauty in such an arid place.

custom.alt: Our introduction to the Karoo dining room.
custom.caption: Our introduction to the Karoo dining room.

custom.alt: Each hut has a deck - perfect for sundowners and early morning coffee.
custom.caption: Each hut has a deck - perfect for sundowners and early morning coffee.

custom.alt: A wonderful outdoor bathroom.
custom.caption: A wonderful outdoor bathroom.

custom.alt: Our party taking a breather atop "An Inconvenient Truth" - Gina, Mario, Nick, Graham and Ramon. Our young klipspringer Leandro was probably already on top of the next mountain.
custom.caption: Our party taking a breather atop "An Inconvenient Truth" - Gina, Mario, Nick, Graham and Ramon. Our young klipspringer Leandro was probably already on top of the next mountain.

custom.alt: A typical Baviaan's evening view. We could hear the baboons close by.
custom.caption: A typical Baviaan's evening view. We could hear the baboons close by.

custom.alt: My favourite - the wild mountainous countryside goes on forever.
custom.caption: My favourite - the wild mountainous countryside goes on forever.

custom.alt: Had to take several shots of us next to the rock formations - the sheer size of them was breathtaking. Here we are walking through Birdsong Valley before climbing out onto a plateau.
custom.caption: Had to take several shots of us next to the rock formations - the sheer size of them was breathtaking. Here we are walking through Birdsong Valley before climbing out onto a plateau.

custom.alt: Making our way through a valley, being dwarfed by amazing rock formations.
custom.caption: Making our way through a valley, being dwarfed by amazing rock formations.

custom.alt: Here Mr Cobb the Gentleman Tortoise comes right up to our stoep - perhaps to offer us some of the vegetation he has in his mouth. Fortunately for him we were in the mood for meat.
custom.caption: Here Mr Cobb the Gentleman Tortoise comes right up to our stoep - perhaps to offer us some of the vegetation he has in his mouth. Fortunately for him we were in the mood for meat.
One of my favourite things in Taiwan - a YouBike station. There is something so pleasing to the eye about that row of bicycles! I love to spend hours cycling around the cities.
An innovative way to amuse kids - large or small - bicycles that pump fountains!
What weekends are made for....
One of our favourite spots, for running, chilling, people-watching and cute dog-spotting.
Just love this pic - so much vibrancy and cuteness rolled into one. A common sight at the big intersections.
Chilling in a park with coffee from 7-Eleven. I have had hundreds of specialty coffees but the 7-Eleven latte remains my favourite.
Saturday explorations
This is apparently a North African sausage. It was served hot with caramelised onions and cheese on a croissant. Heavenly - made the South African Wors roll look silly.
Food market at Maji Maji - perfect for brunch!
Not a terribly good pic - but who would want to forget carrying that damn yellow umbrella everywhere, using it only once and then forgetting it at the YouBike station.
Torrential rains at the Flower Market along the river
Cycling along the river after the rain - beautiful reflections.
A bit of info never goes amiss...
Arb bit of rough here - probably from Rotheram
Walking around the dam is beautiful - I would love to go back when it's slightly warmer and do the whole route as a run!
En famille at the dam wall....
Not all of us feel the cold though...
And a very impressive dam wall it is!
And here we have the Mafia of Derwent extrating their payment of breadcrumbs.
Some more suspicious-looking characters admiring an engineering feat from more than 100 years ago..
Very inviting if you are wearing the right kit....
Like we sip on cappuccino in Hyde Park every day...
Strolling along the Serpentine
Looking nonchalant in Hyde Park
Who would have thought that an Old Goat could be spotted here...
Harrods - an unusual angle!
Knightsbridge - old buildings, old money, black cabs scurrying everywhere. Time for us to move on though....
And so through Knightsbridge, from Hyde Park to Harrods
Hyde Park swans are very smooth and white - quite unlike the rough swans up Rotheram way.
Cycling out of town to find lunch and to see  Qihou Fort, built in the 18th century to protect Kaohsiung Harbour.
Taking the ferry, bicycles and all, across Kaohsiung Harbour to Qijin Town on Cijin Island. The town was founded by fisherman in the 17th century.
Island bound....
Every island needs a surf school....
And a "Sunset Bar".....
Where one can drink delicious ciders and ponder the meaning of life...
Looking from the fort over Kaohsiung Harbour to the Mainland
The town of Qijin seen from the abandoned fort
A more sophisticated ferry to get to Xiao Liu Qiu
Looking around Xiao Liu Qiu
Hiring snorkels to swim with the sea turtles - even the dogs go snorkelling here.
Enjoying the late afternoon sun after swimming with the turtles....
An ancient school just outside the town of Jiji in Nantou County
Beautiful old buildings in the grey drizzle
Wuchang Temple in Jiji was constructed in 1923 and then destroyed by the 1999 Jiji earthquake.  It still stands as a reminder of the devastation and sadness.
During the quake the first floor collapsed, leaving the roof resting askew on the foundation.
Millions of dollars were raised in order to build a new temple near the ruins of the old one.
Sampling egg rolls at Jiji Station, another historic building that had to be rebuilt after the 1999 earthquake.
A lovely picture of happy cyclists - taken before the really steep part began!
Tunnel coming up - luckily a well-lit tunnel.
I was sad to part with my steed for the day, aptly named Horse.
Lovely old stonework
Beautiful mountain views from our cycle path.
The same spot - the many bridges over the Love River change colour every few minutes. Very amusing for old goats from the rural areas.
The night lights of Kaohsiung are dazzling and glitzy but the mood is very laid back. Have a drink on your ambles along the river while choosing a place to eat.
The Love River showing off her colours - spot the gondola, very romantic.
The paths along the river are beautifully kept,  perfect for our running.
A magic antique shop where you can find anything your heart desires. I kept expecting an ancient Mandarin wizard to pop out of a wardrobe.
Steps up to the British Consulate, built in the 1860's. Spare a thought for the tradesmen delivering all the gin and tonic.
Standing outside the British Consulate - colonial-style red buildings,  formal gardens and panoramic views. Life was good back then if you happened to be British.

On the way to the British Consulate there is an arty section of the city where this rather well-endowed guy watches over proceedings. I think he may be a wolf - a wolf that is partial to spending time in the gym, but clearly without steroids.
Spot the sneaky croc...
Spot the hyena's head next to the car window - it was that close! Unfortunately on Dad's side of the car so couldn't snap it properly.
The Southern Ground Hornbill aka Death Birds on Rietfontein - haven't seen ours for ages and apparently they are becoming very rare.
Watching them closely while we put our tent up - turn your back for a sec and your veg supply for the week is gone!
Day One at the Zebra Restaurant. The one lioness is guarding while the other goes off for a drink. Hard to capture without a lens that costs the same as a small car!
You could call this my piece de resistance - it's not every day that a baboon shows you his penis.
What can one say about the good old gnu? He doesn't like to pose and is quite hard to capture. He normally hangs with the zebras who like to hog the limelight.
The kudu is such an elegant buck - the ears have the most gorgeous colours inside them.
The long road home after a day of amusing tourists...
The Legendary Leopard Tortoise is named not just for his colouring - when this boy gets up on those legs he can move - you have to be quick with that camera.

The older giraffes may apply for position of "Tourist Bait" - as such they position themselves very near the gates of the park nonchalantly showing off their beauty. It's a hard job but someone has to do it.
It's obligatory to add a pic of an impala. I'm bummed that I chopped off his feet though.
Lots of youngsters here - it appeared to be a primary school for giraffes.
The Lesser Spotted Wild Goat - can take more than 40 years to domesticate this beast.
Ta da! My personal favourite - presenting the marabou stork aka the undertaker. Google him - he is fascinating.
And there he goes, off to make evil plans with other hyenas.
So close I could fill the screen, but very peaceful, only interested in munching on the greenery.
Within seconds of us stopping at Pretoriuskop this monkey had stolen Dad's peach out of a plastic bag in the back of the vehicle!
Splish, splash, I was taking a bath....

Day Two at the Zebra Restaurant - we were expecting hyenas and vultures, but no, the same two lionesses were still there. The one has gorged itself to the extent of lying on its back with paws in the air.
No collection of Kruger pics is complete without a shot of an elephant's bum.
The hyena is the most fascinating beast. This one taken through a rainy windscreen looks even more sinister than usual.
Just doing what they do best - outshining the poor old gnu.
The nursery school on it's way back from a mud bath.
Spring bulbs popping their heads through...
A quick trip to the Sheffield Botanical Gardens
Chez Corcie - home of a rather famous bull terrier and her dachshund sidekick.
The Hound Manager
A lovely pic for which I must give Michael credit!
A cup of tea - very British!
The Corcies' local pub - yummy food!
When in Yorkshire....
This could be a set off Midsomer Murders
These hanging baskets are planted each season by the Council - so pretty.
Only the English know how to make a village truly villagey.
And down we go...
Lols trying to look relaxed in her role as herder of cats....
And the pub was closed - big disappointment, especially as our tube riding and herding of cats had worked up a thirst.
Was hoping for artsy-fartsy - you know, all movement and light, but you get the idea...
Piccadilly Circus on the way home - I cut off Eros' head but that's what you get if you set yourself up as the Greek God of Love.
The hustle and bustle of Piccadilly - it deserves more than a passing glance.
Edgeware Road - our home station for the duration...
This majestic boy guards the entrance to the National Museum of Natural Science in Taichung.
Yes you can order a dinosaur from Takealot.com
This little guy is a master of camouflage. Only his feet rustling the leaves and the blue feathers on his head gave him away.
The futuristic looking Rainforest Greenhouse at the Museum is guarded by a giant insect. Unfortunately it was Sunday and the Greenhouse was closed.
A turtle with a following of fish hoping for a snack to be dropped in the peaceful surrounds of the Museum.
I think I was more excited than the children by the Hall of Dinosaurs.
Camden Lock on Regent Canal, part of London's canal network.
One has to have a pic with Tower Bridge in the background but the light was all wrong. Note to self - visit Tower Bridge in the late afternoon!
Looking out from Trafalgar Square - one of my favourite pics
Camden Town. Lols has lost her herd - or is she trying to hurl herself under that car?

Daffodils at the Tower. Look carefully and see the statues of lions - this is to remind us of the Royal Menagerie that until 1828 was kept in the Tower. Lion bones dating back 600 years have been found on the site.
A lovely pic of the Herder Of Cats with the Main Cat!
Steph looks like she is about to yawn and the Old Goat is caught on his phone but what an awesome pic of Michael.
Camden Market. South Africans do not part easily with pounds but this is definitely a place to do it!
The top entrance to the bear pit - hard to capture in that light, but very creepy.
Mazes, ancient statues and trees centuries old all add to the charm.
Just a glimpse of the opulence of days gone by! We were not allowed up the stairs where ceilings are falling in and silk wallpaper is peeling from the walls.
The stairs down to the bear pit - the actual pit and the tunnel leading to the other entrance in the garden is now closed to the public.
Wentworth Gardens - we spotted deer under these trees, unfazed by the pelting rain.
This is about one third of the facade taken unfortunately in poor light. The centre third is covered in scaffolding at the moment.
The attention to detail is astounding - I look forward to wandering through in good weather on my next visit..
Showing off my running skills...photo courtesy of my web developer.
Everything grows beautifully on the lush mountains of the Park. I spotted these beauties near our campsite.
Our campsite in Yushan National Park
Steep winding roads and precarious parking spots are the order of the day in the mountains.
Wending our way up through lush forests to a waterfall.
Above the rooftops - love these buildings nestled into the mountains, often at precarious angles.
A swinging bridge - an amazing structure way up the mountain in the middle of nowhere. The Taiwanese know how to build a hiking trail!
